title: 109_s1744
content: The "Price Gouging Act of 2005" prohibits price gouging following major disasters, amending the Federal Trade Commission Act to include protection from price gouging. The "Price Gouging Act of 2005" defines terms like 'affected area', 'price gouging', 'supplier', and 'unconscionably excessive price' in the context of major disasters declared by the President. The "Price Gouging Act of 2005" defines price gouging as charging prices significantly higher than the average in the affected area before a major disaster declaration. The Commission consults with relevant authorities to determine if suppliers are engaging in price gouging. The "Price Gouging Act of 2005" prohibits suppliers from charging excessively high prices for gasoline or diesel fuel in an affected area after a major disaster declaration. The Commission establishes a hotline for reporting price gouging incidents and distributes informational materials to help residents detect and avoid price gouging. The Price Gouging Act of 2005 prohibits suppliers from charging excessive prices for gasoline or diesel fuel in affected areas after a disaster. The Commission conducts investigations and imposes civil penalties of up to $500,000 for violations. The Price Gouging Act of 2005 prohibits suppliers from charging excessive prices for gasoline or diesel fuel in affected areas after a disaster. Violators may face civil penalties of up to $500,000, special and punitive damages, attorney's fees, litigation costs, disgorgement of profits, and any other appropriate relief determined by the court. Additionally, suppliers knowingly committing an offense may be imprisoned for up to 1 year. Victims of violations can bring civil actions for loss or damage. The Price Gouging Act of 2005 prohibits suppliers from charging excessive prices for gasoline or diesel fuel in affected areas after a disaster. Violators may face civil penalties, including disgorgement, damages, injunctive relief, attorney's fees, and costs of litigation. State attorneys general can also take legal action on behalf of residents for similar relief. This section does not preempt any State law. The Price Gouging Act of 2005 prohibits suppliers from charging excessive prices for gasoline or diesel fuel in affected areas after a disaster. The Commission is required to submit an annual report to Congress detailing price gouging complaints, investigations, and enforcement actions related to major disasters. The Price Gouging Act of 2005 requires the Commission to evaluate the toll-free hotline and program effectiveness and make recommendations for additional actions. The Commission must also define 'gross disparity' within 180 days of enactment. SEC. 3. EFFECT OF ACT: This Act does not impact the Federal Trade Commission's authority regarding price gouging actions.
